metadata.title: Preparation and characterization of Nano-graphite/TiO2 composite photoelectrode for photoelectrocatalytic degradation of hazardous pollutant

reparation and characterization of Nano-graphite/TiO2 composite hotoelectrode for photoelectrocatalytic degradation of hazardous ollutant
ong Li a,b, Jialin Jia a,b, Yuhang Zhang a,b, Na Wang a,b, Xiaolei Guo a,b, Xiujuan Yu a,b,∗
Department of Environmental Science and Engineering, Heilongjiang University, Xuefu Road 74, Nangang District, Harbin 150080, Heilongjiang Province, R China Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering Process & Technology for High-efficiency Conversion, Harbin, College of Heilongjiang Province, PR China
i g h l i g h t s
Nano-G/TiO2 photoelectrode was prepared by the sol-gel and hot-press methods. Nano-G/TiO2 photoelectrode exhibited high charges separation performance. Nano-G/TiO2 photoelectrode displayed excellent PEC activity. Contribution of active species for degradation of RhB was investigated. Enhanced PEC mechanism of NanoG/TiO2 photoelectrode was proposed.
g r a p h i c a l a b s t r a c t
The chemical-coupling Nano-graphite(G)/TiO2 composite was successfully prepared via a modified solgel method and then was fabricated as a photoelectrode by the hot-press approach. Nano-G/TiO2 photoelectrode displayed high PEC activity and stability, which was attributed to Nano-G as suitable electronic conductors to promote charge collection and charge transport as well as the synergetic effect between PC and EC reactions.
r t i c l e i n f o
rticle history: eceived 10 December 2015 eceived in revised form 19 April 2016 ccepted 20 April 2016 vailable online 27 April 2016
eywords: ano-graphite iO2 hotoelectrocatalysis hotoelectrode
a b s t r a c t
Nano-graphite(Nano-G)/TiO2 composite photoelectrode was fabricated via sol-gel reaction, followed by the hot-press approach. The morphology, structure and light absorption capability of composite was characterized by various characterizations. The photoelectrochemical property and photoelectrocatalytic(PEC) activity of photoelectrode were also investigated. Results revealed that anatase TiO2 nanoparticles with an average diameter of 10 nm were dispersed uniformly on the thickness of 2–3 nm Nano-G, and Ti O C bond was formed. The absorption edge of Nano-G/TiO2 photoelectrode was redshifted towards low energy region and the enhanced visible light absorption was obtained. The charge transfer resistance of Nano-G/TiO2 photoelectrode was significantly decreased after the addition of NanoG. And its transient photoinduced current was 10.5 times the value achieved using TiO2 electrode. Nano-G/TiO2 photoelectrode displayed greatly enhanced PEC activity of 99.2% towards the degradation of
henol phenol, which was much higher than the 29.1% and 58.3% degradation seen on TiO2 and Nano-G electrode, respectively. The highly efficient and stable PEC activity of Nano-G/TiO2 photoelectrode was attributed to the synergy effect between pho ity and higher separation effic of reactive species to the PEC d

tocatalysis and electrocatalysis, as well as enhanced light absorption abiliency of photogenerated charge carriers. Moreover, contribution of series egradation of Nano-G/TiO2 photoelectrode was determined.

t t m i d b t
D. Li et al. / Journal of Haza
. Introduction
Phenol, which is not only a versatile raw and intermediate hemical material but also a common by-product in numerous ndustrial enterprises, has been considered as the environmenally hazardous material and listed as a priority contaminant by nited States Environmental Protection Agency because it can esult in damage and highly toxic effect on ecological system nd living organisms even at low concentration [1–3]. Convenional technologies for the treatment of phenolic wastewater ncluding adsorption [4], coagulation/precipitation [5], chemical xidation [6], biological treatment [7] and electrochemical oxidaion [8] have the following drawbacks: incomplete degradation, igh probability of generating secondary pollutants, large energy onsumption. Thus, new techniques with low energy consumpion and high efficiency have become an urgent goal for treatment f phenolic wastewater. In the last decades, photocatalytic (PC) xidation using semiconductor materials, in particular on TiO2 as been proposed as an efficient method for water treatment ecause of its outstanding advantages of nontoxicity, stability, low ost, and strong photo-oxidizing power [9]. Nevertheless, practial application of TiO2 was greatly restricted owing to its large and gap energy, high recombination of charge carriers and difcult recycling of pulverous TiO2 photocatalysts [10,11]. After that,
great deal of efforts has been carried out to overcome these efects.
Recently, the integration of TiO2 nanomaterials with carbon aterials, such as graphene [12], graphdiyne [12], carbon nanoubes [13], expanded graphite [14,15] and graphite [16], has ttracted widespread attention. Among these, a great interest has een dedicated to improve the PC activity of TiO2 towards polutants using carbon nanotubes and graphene [12,13,17,18]. The nhanced PC activity has been mainly ascribed to these materils as the electron reservoir to restrain the charge recombination. ia [16] and Yu et al. [14] had reported that graphite and expanded raphite could extend greatly the light absorption ability and retard he charge recombination of TiO2, leading to an enhanced PC ctivity. Nano-G, owing to the two-dimensional nano-structure, ossesses the character of enough specific surfaces, well electrical erformances and large surface energy, apart from the common haracteristic of the graphite and expanded graphite [19]. Qiang t al. [20] reported that the Nano-G through ultrasound dispersing xpanded graphite showed the higher electrochemical properties nd electrocatalytic activity than that of expanded graphite and atural flake graphite. In addition, the preparation of Nano-G was imilar to the graphene which can be prepared via exfoliation of raphite. The structure of Nano-G consists of thin graphite flake and ew-layer graphene [21–23]. What is more, Nano-G is easier and heaper to manufacture and can be easily large-scale produced than raphene, graphdiyne and carbon nanotubes [19]. And the atoms on he surface of Nano-G are in the state of serious defect and exhibit igh activity, they can combine with other atoms or compounds ery well [24]. Hence, it is a great promising prospect to design and evelop Nano-G-based materials for practical application. Accordngly, we consider that combination of TiO2 and Nano-G was a otential and effective strategy to control simultaneously excelent light absorbability, electron transferability, chemical stability nd PC activity.
Also, in the recent studies, many research [25–27] results show hat photoelectrocatalysis is an efficient approach to facilitate he separation and transfer of photoinduced charge carriers. And
any reports [1,28–30] have also proved that the PEC oxidation s more efficient than photocatalysis or electrocatalysis alone for egrading organic contaminants by exploiting the synergistic effect etween photocatalysis and electrocatalysis. To our knowledge, here have been few reports about the construction and systematic
Materials 315 (2016) 1–10
investigation of Nano-G/TiO2 composite photoelectrode for PEC degradation of phenol.
In the present work, Nano-G/TiO2 composite was obtained through a simple sol-gel method. The physicochemical performances of Nano-G/TiO2 composite were investigated systematically. In addition, we reported a simply hot-press method to fabricate composite photoelectrode with titanium mesh as a support. The immobilization of the Nano-G/TiO2 composite on a conductive material as a photoelectrode can effectively avoid losses in the recovery process. The introduced Nano-G in composite can serve as suitable electronic conductors to increase the charge separation and enhance light absorption. The as-prepared Nano-G/TiO2 photoelectrode was applied for PEC degradation of hazardous organic contaminants (phenol in this case). As-expected, NanoG/TiO2 photoelectrode exhibited high PEC activity and stability. Moreover, the enhanced catalytic mechanism was proposed.
2. Experimental
2.1. Preparation of Nano-G/TiO2 composite
All chemicals used in our study were analytical grade and were used without any further purification. Nano-G was fabricated according to our previous works, which have been described elsewhere [20]. In detail, graphite intercalation compounds (GICs) were prepared through the chemical oxidation of natural flake graphite (200 mesh) employing perchloric acid and potassium permanganate as intercalation agent and oxidant, respectively. Then, GICs were rinsed close to neutrality with distilled water via a vacuum filter, and dried at the 353 K in an oven to generate the dry expandable graphite. Afterwards, expanded graphite (EG) was obtained through thermal exfoliation of expandable graphite in a microwave oven for 20 s. Subsequently, the EG was dispersed in aqueous alcohol solution, and then the suspension liquid was subjected to 12 h smashing in an ultrasonic bath. The resulting mixture was filtered, washed by distilled water for several times, and dried, to obtain the Nano-G.
Nano-G/TiO2 composite was prepared by a modified sol-gel method. The concrete process went as follows: Tetrabutyl titanate was added dropwise into absolute ethanol under continuously vigorous magnetic stirring, denoting as solution A. Meanwhile, the absolute ethanol, deionized water and HNO3 were mingled with a volume ratio of 5:5:1, and served as the titrant, forming solution B. The TiO2-sol was obtained through adding B dropwise into A under vigorously stirring. Next step, 25 mL of TiO2-sol was slowly added into a 100 mL silica beaker containing the desired amount of Nano-G. The obtained black sol was continuously stirred for 2 h, and was then aged in the atmosphere for 6 h, and dried at 353 K in an oven for 13 h, the Nano-G/TiO2 precursor was produced. Eventually, the Nano-G/TiO2 xerogel was calcinated in a muffle furnace at 723 K for 2 h to obtain crystalline Nano-G/TiO2 composite. Based on the volume of the TiO2-sol, the theoretical TiO2 content in NanoG/TiO2 was 35%. As a comparison, pure TiO2 calcinated at 723 K was prepared under the same conditions in the absence of Nano-G.
2.2. Preparation of Nano-G/TiO2 photoelectrode
Nano-G/TiO2 photoelectrode was fabricated through rolling Nano-G and PTFE latex, in which the titanium mesh (Ti-mesh) was served as the substrate. Firstly, 0.5 g Nano-G/TiO2 composite was effectively mixed with 5.0 g ethanol under vigorously stirring in water bath at 338 K. Subsequently, 1.5 g 10% PTFE as a binder was added dropwise into the solutions under stirring. Next step, the resulting mixture was rolled repeatedly to fabricate Nano-G/TiO2 composite photoelectrode of 2 cm × 4.5 cm on a machine with

i-mesh as the support, and followed by boiling in boiling water. inally, the obtained Nano-G/TiO2 composite electrode was dried n an oven at 353 K. For comparison, pure TiO2 and Nano-G photolectrode was prepared in the same process.
.3. Characterization of Nano-G/TiO2 composite
Field emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM, Hitachi -4800) and Transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEOL JEM010) were employed to characterize the micromorphology of the s-prepared Nano-G/TiO2 composite. AFM imaging performed by eans of an atomic force microscope (AFM, SPM 5100) in the taping mode. The crystalline structures of the Nano-G/TiO2 were onfirmed using a X-ray diffractometer (XRD, D8 Advance, Bruker) quipped with Cu K radiation source ( = 1.5418 Å), at an accelrating voltage of 40 kV and an applied current of 30 mA. Raman pectra were carried out on a Jobin Yvon HR800 Raman specrometer. Fourier Transform Infrared spectra (FT-IR) were obtained sing a spectrum one spectrometer (PE) with KBr as diluents. -ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Kratos-AXIS ULTRA DLD) quipped with Al K X-ray source was conducted to examine he electronic states of Nano-G/TiO2. The optical performance of he Nano-G/TiO2 were analyzed through Ultraviolet–vis diffuse eflectance spectroscopy (UV–vis DRS) using a TU-1901 specrophotometer equipped with an integrating sphere using BaSO4 s the background. The surface photovoltage (SPV) spectroscopy easurement was performed with a home-built apparatus which as been described in detail elsewhere [31].
.4. Tests of photoelectrochemical performances
The photoelectrochemical characteristics of the as-prepared ano-G/TiO2 composite photoelectrodes were performed in a
onventional three-electrode configuration with Nano-G/TiO2 lectrode, Pt foil and Ag/AgCl electrode as the photoanode, counter lectrode and reference electrode, respectively. The transient phoocurrent response of the samples was recorded on a LK 3200 lectrochemical station. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy EIS) plots of the Nano-G/TiO2 electrode were measured using a QSTA128 N workstation under Xenon lamp irradiation with or ithout an applied voltage in a frequency range from 0.01 Hz to 00 MHz. Meanwhile, 0.1 mol L−1 Na2SO4 solution was served as he supporting electrolyte. In addition, a 350 W Xenon lamp with rradiating wavelength ranged from 200 to 1200 nm was used as the imulated solar light source with the light intensity of the photoande surface of 29.8 KLux. The distance between the Nano-G/TiO2 hotoanode and the lamp source was approximately 15 cm.
.5. Evaluation of photoelectrocatalytic performance
The electrocatalytic (EC), photocatalytic (PC) and photoelecrocatalytic (PEC) activities of the as-prepared Nano-G/TiO2 hotoelectrode were evaluated by the degradation of phenol with n initial concentration of 25 mg L−1. The catalytic reactions were arried out in a homemade cylindrical quartz reactor, which conained 40 mL phenol solution. In the PC experiment, the working lectrode was vertically immersed into the reaction solution with n active area of ca. 9 cm2. Upon being vigorously stirred for 30 min n the dark to establish the adsorption-desorption equilibrium of henol on the photoelectrode, the PC reaction was initiated by illuinating the system with a 350 W Xenon lamp. The applied voltage as controlled at +2 V by a two-channel output DC power supply DH1715A-5) in the EC experiment. It should be noted that the PEC rocess was the combination of PC and EC process. In EC and PEC rocess, the supporting electrolyte was 0.1 mol L−1 Na2SO4 soluion. The degraded solution was collected and measured using the
Materials 315 (2016) 1–10 3
4-aminoantipyrine spectrophotometric method at 510 nm on a T6 UV–vis spectrophotometer. In addition, the contribution of series of active species was determined during the removal of rhodamine B (RhB) through scavenger detection experiments.
3. Results and discussion
3.1. SEM, TEM and AFM analysis
Morphological information of Nano-G and Nano-G/TiO2 composite were displayed in Fig. 1. SEM images of Nano-G and Nano-G/TiO2 composite were shown in Fig. 1a and b, respectively. The Nano-G was two-dimensional sheets looking like pieces of paper to some degree and seemingly several few-layers graphene flakes which are partially overlapped with each other (Fig. 1a). Compared with Fig. 1a and b can be clearly distinguished that TiO2 particles were located at the surface of Nano-G. Fig. 1c and d represented typical TEM images for as-prepared Nano-G/TiO2 composite. It can be observed from Fig. 1c that the thickness of Nano-G sheet with micrometers-long wrinkles in Nano-G/TiO2 composite was thin. Under the condition of high magnification, the TiO2 particles revealed an equiaxed geometry and a narrow size uniform distribution with diameters of 10 nm (Fig. 1d). Recently, our group [14] has reported that TiO2 nanoparticles in the expandedG/TiO2 composite with diameter range of 20–30 nm were formed on the expanded-G. Thus, in this study, the structure of Nano-G sheet in Nano-G/TiO2 composite could maximize the interfacial contact between Nano-G and TiO2, and the aggregation of TiO2 was well prevented. The inset of Fig. 1d was the HRTEM image of Nano-G/TiO2 composite. The lattice distance was determined to be 0.35 nm, which could be indexed to the (101) crystal plane of anatase TiO2 [32]. To determine the thickness of Nano-G, AFM images were carried out on the silicon substrate and shown in Fig. 1e, which clearly showed Nano-G with the thickness of approximately 2–3 nm. Some literature reports that the heights in the range of 0.34–1.2 nm were considered as monolayer graphene [22,33]. Thus, such a thickness of 2–3 nm related to the overlapping of 4–6 layers of graphene.
3.2. XRD and Raman analysis
X-ray diffraction patterns of the Nano-G, pure TiO2 and NanoG/TiO2 composite were displayed in Fig. 2a. Noticeable, pure TiO2 showed the anatase (JCPDS file no. 21-1272), rutile (JCPDS file no. 21-1276) diffraction peaks at 25.2◦ and 27.4◦, respectively, which were denoted as A and R in the XRD patterns [34]. For Nano-G, the diffraction peak at 26.6◦ was assigned to the characteristic diffraction peak of (002) plane of Nano-G (JCPDS file no. 41-1487) [14,20]. The XRD pattern of Nano-G/TiO2 composite consisted of characteristic peaks of Nano-G and anatase TiO2. After being composited with Nano-G, the TiO2 nanoparticles in Nano-G/TiO2 composite in an anatase state, no diffraction peaks from the rutile phase were observed, suggesting that the addition of Nano-G for the NanoG/TiO2 could inhibit the formation of rutile TiO2.

ome defects or impurity atoms in the hexagonal graphitic layers, hile the G-peak belonged to the E2g mode of graphite, which was n account of the sp2-bonded carbon atoms in a two-dimensional exagonal graphitic layer [20,36]. The Raman spectrum of pure ano-G merely consisted of D and G-bands of graphite. Thus, it an be confirmed the existence of Nano-G in Nano-G/TiO2 comosite. Besides, the Nano-G/TiO2 exhibited an enhancement of D nd G-bands intensity compared with Nano-G. And the radio of the ntensity of the D-band to that of the G-band (ID/IG) in Nano-G and ano-G/TiO2 were approximately 0.041 and 0.036, respectively.
.3. FT-IR and XPS analysis
Fig. 3a showed the FT-IR spectra of Nano-G, TiO2 and Nano/TiO2 composite. The absorption peaks at 3398 cm−1 and
ages of Nano-G/TiO2 composite (c, d) and AFM image of Nano-G (e).
1620 cm−1 resulted from the O H stretching vibration of water[37]. For the spectrum of as-prepared TiO2, 625 cm−1 was attributed to the stretching vibration of Ti O Ti bond and Ti O bond [38]. As to the Nano-G/TiO2 composite, the peaks in the spectra of Nano-G and TiO2 still existed. This illustrated that the sol-gel method could effectively combine Nano-G and TiO2, which was in agreement with the XRD results. However, the intensity of Ti O and Ti O Ti peaks at 625 cm−1 was markedly decreased in Nano-G/TiO2 composite, which might be attributed to the light shielding by the Nano-G. Furthermore, the absorption peak corresponding to Ti O Ti bond and Ti O bond of TiO2 in Nano-G/TiO2 composite FT-IR spectra shifted to 745 cm−1. This shift was ascribed to the combination of Ti O Ti bond and Ti O C bond [14,39]. Typically, Zhang [40] and Qiu et al. [18] indicated that Ti O C stretching vibration could display low frequency band at around 798 cm−1. Fig. 3b showed

ig. 2. (a) XRD patterns of TiO2, Nano-G and Nano-G/TiO2 composite, (b) Raman pectra of Nano-G and Nano-G/TiO2 composite (The inset showed the enlargement f Raman shift ranging from 100 to 1000 cm−1).
he high-resolution XPS spectrum of C1s for Nano-G/TiO2 composte. The dominated C1s peak of Nano-G/TiO2 centered at around 84.6 eV was assigned to C C bonds (sp2) of graphite [16,19,35]. dditionally, the two minor peaks at around 285.8 and 288.6 eV ere characteristic of the oxygen bound species C O and Ti O C, espectively, indicating the interaction between the Nano-G and iO2 [11,41]. Hence, the above analysis further confirmed the sucessful fabrication of chemical-coupling Nano-G/TiO2 composite.
.4. DRS and SPV analysis
The optical performance of the TiO2 and Nano-G/TiO2 photolectrode were studied and given in Fig. 4a. In the UV–vis diffuse eflectance spectra, the TiO2 and Nano-G/TiO2 photoelectrode dislayed typical photoabsorption with an intense transition in the V region of the spectra, which corresponded to the inherent and gap energy of pure TiO2 [42]. Nano-G exhibited intense hotoabsorbance over the entire visible light region. In contrast, he Nano-G/TiO2 photoelectrode exhibited increased absorption oth in UV and visible light region, which was attributed to the ncorporation of Nano-G. Moreover, the absorption edge of the
Nano-G/TiO2 photoelectrode showed an obvious red-shift to higher wavelength probably because of the generation of Ti O C bond between Nano-G and TiO2 [40,43]. The tangent drawn revealed an absorbance maximum of 417 nm and 445 nm for the TiO2 and NanoG/TiO2 composite, corresponding to band gap energy of 3.0 eV and 2.8 eV, respectively.
To investigate the surface charge transfer behavior of asprepared Nano-G/TiO2 composite, the surface photovoltage (SPV) spectra were performed. Generally speaking, the stronger are the SPV signals, the lower are the recombination rate of photogenerated charge carriers. Fig. 4b displayed SPV response of TiO2, Nano-G and Nano-G/TiO2 composite. By comparison, no SPV signals were detected for Nano-G sample. For the conspicuous SPV signal at around 345 nm in the TiO2 and Nano-G/TiO2 samples, it can be primarily originated from the electronic transition from O2− antibonding orbital to the lowest empty orbital of Ti4+ (O2p → Ti3d) [31]. In addition, an obvious broad SPV response in the visible light range of 400–480 nm was observed for the Nano-G/TiO2 composite, which was thanks to the sub-band-gap transition caused by generation of Ti O C bonds [16]. Nano-G/TiO2 composite revealed stronger SPV response at the wavelength of 300–480 nm in comparison with TiO2, suggesting that Nano-G/TiO2 exhibited the higher separation efficiency of photoexcited charge carriers than that of

q c o e c i t a c t
ig. 4. UV–vis DRS (a) and SPV (b) spectra of TiO2, Nano-G and Nano-G/TiO2 comosite photoelectrodes.
iO2. This phenomenon can be primarily attributed to the two easons as follows. (A) The incorporation of Nano-G as superior lectronic conductors could attract the photoexcited electrons from iO2 to effectively promote the charge transfer and separation. (B) he combination of Nano-G and TiO2 could generate new Ti O C ands to narrow the intrinsic band gap of TiO2. As a result, the hotogenerated electrons could be easily excited by visible light, esulting in a higher concentration charge separation.
.5. Photoelectrochemical properties
Photoelectrochemical measurements are usually applied to ualitatively study the excitation and transfer of photoinduced harge carriers in PC and PEC reactions [10,11]. Hence, the effect f Nano-G on the charge transport performance in Nano-G/TiO2 lectrode was investigated through EIS. Fig. 5a compared typial EIS Nyquist plots of Nano-G, TiO2 and Nano-G/TiO2 electrodes n dark. The diameter of the semicircle on the Nyquist plot of he Nano-G/TiO2 electrode was smaller than that of the Nano-G nd TiO2 electrode, indicating that the electron transfer resistance ontrolling the kinetics at the contact interface between the phooelectrode and electrolyte solution, which was mainly dependent
on the component content of the photoelectrode. The smallest diameter of the semicircle for Nano-G/TiO2 electrode reflected the lowest resistance of the interfacial charge transfer [44,45]. Therefore, it could be concluded that the presence of Nano-G in Nano-G/TiO2 electrode can contribute to the electron accepting and transporting, then the effective charge separation. Furthermore, EIS response of Nano-G/TiO2 electrode measured under external applied voltage was shown in Fig. 5b. As seen from Fig. 5b, with the assistance of external voltage, the diameter of the semicircle of Nano-G/TiO2 electrode obviously decreased under Xenon lamp irradiation, suggesting that the photogenerated electrons and holes pairs were more efficiently separated and transferred, and subsequently should lead to a higher catalytic activity for degradation of phenol under external electrical field.
Fig. 6 showed the photocurrent responses of the TiO2 and NanoG/TiO2 photoelectrodes through several on-off cycles under Xenon lamp illumination. As can be seen from Fig. 6, the photocurrent response increased rapidly as soon as the light was switched on, while immediately returned to its initial value as soon as the illumination of light on the as-prepared photoelectrode was turned off, suggesting that the photoinduced current was absolutely dependent on the performance of the photoelectrode. The photocurrent intensity of both as-prepared electrodes did not exhibit obvious changes after on-off cycles, namely, the photocurrent responses of

oth electrodes were stable and reproducible. The magnitude of he transient photocurrent from an irradiated electrode is decided y the separation efficiency of the photogenerated hole-electron h+/e−) pairs [46]. The transient photocurrent of Nano-G/TiO2 elecrode was approximately 7.64 mA, larger than that of pure TiO2 lectrode (0.73 mA) by a factor of 10.5 under Xenon lamp irradition. The photocurrent enhancement of Nano-G/TiO2 electrode onfirmed the prevention of charge carrier recombination. This esult combined with EIS analysis could further authenticate that he introduction of Nano-G in Nano-G/TiO2 electrode could act as
potent charge mobile layer to accept the photoexcited electrons rom TiO2 and transfer them to the external circuit rapidly because f the decrease of electron transfer resistance. Thus, a higher hotocurrent was observed in the Nano-G/TiO2 electrode. Some litratures had also indicated that the photocurrent of composites of itania with carbon materials revealed similarly increases [47–49].
oreover, the photocurrent value (7.64 mA) of Nano-G/TiO2 elecrode was higher than that of expanded-G/TiO2 (6.87 mA) by a actor of 1.1 in our previous report [14], which might ascribe to that he nano-structure of Nano-G possess better electrical properties han for expand-G.
.6. PEC performance
Fig. 7 compared the removal efficiency of phenol between diferent degradation processes, including PC, EC and PEC degradation s well as adsorption in dark on TiO2, Nano-G and Nano-G/TiO2 hotoelectrodes within 90 min. We could find from Fig. 7 that he PEC reactions displayed the highest degradation efficiency in hese photoelectrodes. It was worth noting that the EC activities f the Nano-G and Nano-G/TiO2 photoelectrodes were both higher han for their PC activities. This indicated that direct electrochemcal oxidation process was produced on the surface of as-prepared lectrode. Nano-G photoelectrode without TiO2 showed significant nhancement EC (51.3%) and PEC (58.3%) performances in phenol egradation compared to that of pure TiO2 (EC 12.4%, PEC 29.1%), hile the PC activity of pure TiO2 (28.3%) was higher than that
f bare Nano-G (17.4%), but much lower than the EC performance f bare Nano-G (51.3%). It can be concluded that 58.3% of phenol egradation using bare Nano-G elecreode in PEC reaction could be ainly ascribed to the prominent EC degradation of Nano-G [19]. hese results implied that bare Nano-G exhibited superiorly elecrochemical oxidation ability but lower photocatalysis than pure iO2. In addition, a much higher degradation efficiency of phenol as obtained on the Nano-G/TiO2 photoelectrode in all degradation
processes in comparison with the Nano-G and TiO2 photoelectrodes. Namely, Nano-G/TiO2 photoelectrode showed highest PC, EC and PEC activity, for which 51.6%, 66.5% and 99.2% of phenol could be degraded within 90 min, respectively. The higher EC degradation efficiency for phenol on Nano-G/TiO2 electrode than for Nano-G was ascribed to that the incorporation of TiO2 could improve the electrochemical performance, number of active sites and formation of •OH radicals of the Nano-G, which were evidenced by our previous paper [19]. And such significant enhancement of PEC efficiency of Nano-G/TiO2 electrode could be attributed to the aspects as follows: (a) synergetic effect between PC process and EC process; (b) the decorated Nano-G significantly improved the light absorbance ability; (c) the presence of Nano-G in the Nano-G/TiO2 photoelectrode and external applied potential were favorable to reduce the transfer resistance of electrons and improve the separation of the photogenerated charge carriers. These results agreed well with DRS, SPV and photoelectrochemical properties analysis. Moreover, the removal efficiency of phenol using pure TiO2, bare Nano-G and Nano-G/TiO2 resulted from adsorption in dark after 90 min were 5.2%, 3.7% and 4.3%, respectively.
Fig. 8a displayed the PEC degradation of phenol by Nano-G/TiO2 composite photoelectrodes with different TiO2 content. The degradation efficiency of phenol increased from 58.3% to 99.2% when the TiO2 content was increased from 0 to 35%. But further increasing TiO2 content to 60% decreased the removal efficiency of phenol to 61.5%. The appropriate increase of TiO2 can generate more photoinduced electron-hole pairs resulting in higher concentration of active species and therefore improved degradation. To investigate the recyclability and stability of Nano-G/TiO2 photoelectrode, the PEC decomposition of phenol solution was measured by repeating six cycles under simulated solar light irradiation for 90 min, and the corresponding results were displayed in Fig. 8b. It should be noticed that the used photoelectrode was rinsed through steeping in deionized water after each experiment for 30 min. The PEC performance of Nano-G/TiO2 photoelectrode decreased approximately 2.3% (from 99.2% to 96.9%) after six cycles, implying that the NanoG/TiO2 photoelectrode maintained excellent activity stability and could be adopted as practically stable and viable photoelectrode.
3.7. PEC mechanism
As demonstrated, several active species, for instance OH, O2 , h+ and H2O2, were responsible for PC and PEC degradation process. The roles of the main active species including •OH, •O2−, h+ and H2O2 in the PEC reactions were investigated by different types

f active species scavenging experiments. Fig. 9 exhibited the PEC ctivities of Nano-G/TiO2 photoelectrode for degradation of RhB
−1
10 mg L ) under different conditions. The PEC degradation rate of hB was 99.9% after 60 min of Xenon lamp irradiation without the ddition of the scavengers. As a kind of scavenger for •OH, 30 mmol ert butyl alcohol (TBA) was added into the reaction system [50],
the degradation efficiency of RhB was decreased to the largest extent (34.6%). Nevertheless, the PEC degradation efficiency of RhB decreased moderately with p-benzoquinone (BQ) and ammonium oxalate (AO) as the •O2− scavenger and the hole capturer, respectively [51,52]. In addition, when Fe(II)-EDTA as a scavenger for H2O2 species was added into the PEC reaction system [53], the degradation removal of RhB was inhibited to the minimum extent (from 99.9% to 73.6%) compared with the others scavengers. Hence, we could conclude that each active species played important role in controlling the PEC reaction, and the degradation of RhB was mainly obtained by the contribution of •OH radicals, and to a lesser extent by the participation of •O2−, h+ and H2O2 radicals.
Based on the above experimental findings and analysis, a simple mechanism for the observed PEC process was shown schematically in Fig. 10. When a positive voltage was applied, the direct electrochemical oxidation reaction could be carried out on the as-prepared anode. The adsorbed H2O molecule on the surface of the anode could be catalyzed to generate high active •OH radicals species (Process A) [14]. When the Nano-G/TiO2 photoelectrode was irradiated with Xenon light, TiO2 in the Nano-G/TiO2 composite were excited to produce electron/hole pairs. Afterwards, due to the enormous contact surface area between Nano-G and TiO2 as a result of TiO2 nanoparticles were dispersed uniformly on Nano-G sheet (Fig. 1d), and electrons tended to flow from the higher to lower Fermi level to adjust the Fermi energy levels [54], Nano-G can
f Nano-G/TiO2 composite photoelectrode.

ccept the generated electrons from TiO2. The linkage of TiO2 on ano-G with Ti O C bonds could facilitate the electrons transer. Besides, owing to the formation of Ti O C bonds, more visible ight could be utilized to participate in the PC reaction (Process ) [55], resulting in a higher concentration of charge carriers and C efficiency (Process B). Under the promotion of external posiive voltage, the excited electrons could be migrated from anode o cathode through the conductive substrate and external circuit. ubsequently, the accumulated electrons in cathode and residal photoinduced holes in as-prepared anode could react with he adsorbed O2, OH− or H2O to form the active species such as +, H2O2, •O2− radicals and •OH radicals (Process C), which were esponsible for the mineralization of organic pollutants.
. Conclusions
In summary, the Nano-G/TiO2 composite was obtained through odified sol-gel process, and the efficient Nano-G/TiO2 composte photoelectrode was synthesized and applied to PC, EC and PEC egradation of phenol. The anatase TiO2 nanoparticles with diameers of 10 nm were uniformly supported on the thickness of 2–3 nm ano-G sheets with close contacts, which formed Ti O C bonds etween Nano-G and TiO2. During the PEC degradation process f phenol of Nano-G/TiO2 photoelectrode, PC and EC promoted ach other, which generated a synergistic impact. In addition, ano-G/TiO2 photoelectrode provided a greater degree of removal fficiency for phenol as compared to the TiO2 electrode and Nano-
electrode. The reasons could be ascribed to the presence of ighly conductive Nano-G, external potential and the strong chem-
cal bond between Nano-G and TiO2 nanoparticles, which could ot only enhance the light absorption both in UV and visible ight region, but also efficiently decrease the resistance of elecrons transfer and hinder charge recombination. After further study e noted that the produced hydroxyl radicals as major active pecies were responsible for PEC process. This study provides a imple, efficient and promising material and technique towards the mprovement of the degradation of phenol.

metadata.abstractText: The chemical-coupling Nano-graphite(G)/TiO2 composite was successfully prepared via a modified solgel method and then was fabricated as a photoelectrode by the hot-press approach. Nano-G/TiO2 photoelectrode displayed high PEC activity and stability, which was attributed to Nano-G as suitable electronic conductors to promote charge collection and charge transport as well as the synergetic effect between PC and EC reactions.
